structured_info.title_cn: 考虑多前车预期与通信延迟的协同自适应巡航控制车辆串稳定性分析
structured_info.title_en: String Stability Analysis of Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control Vehicles Considering Multi-Anticipation and Communication Delay
structured_info.abstract: This study investigates the stability of multi-anticipative CACC vehicles with Vehicle-to-Vehicle (V2V) communication delay using Lyapunov methods. Key findings include: (i) The Lyapunov function method overcomes transfer function limitations for multi-anticipative models, while the Lyapunov functional method accurately predicts delay impacts; (ii) Multi-anticipative models ensure traffic stability and high capacity; (iii) Critical instability wavelength follows a power law when acceleration sensitivity is excluded; (iv) Realistic communication delays minimally affect CACC stability.
structured_info.methodology: Lyapunov function method for delay-free systems; Lyapunov functional method for systems with V2V communication delay; numerical simulations of 200-vehicle circular road traffic; sensitivity analysis of safe time headway parameters.
structured_info.conclusion: Multi-anticipation enhances CACC stability while maintaining high throughput. Communication delays (≤0.2s) have negligible destabilizing effects. Instability transitions from long to short wavelength at high spacing sensitivity, following a power law when acceleration sensitivity is excluded.
structured_info.venue: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems

analysis.Overview: Analyzes string stability in Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC) systems with multi-vehicle anticipation and communication delays, contributing to intelligent transportation control theory.
Background_and_Motivation: Commercial ACC vehicles exhibit string instability at low headways, reducing road capacity. CACC systems promise stability but lack analytical frameworks for multi-anticipative models with delays.
Derive closed-form stability conditions for multi-anticipative CACC systems; quantify delay impacts; achieve stability without sacrificing capacity.
Experimental evidence shows ACC instability compromises capacity. Communication-enabled multi-anticipation could resolve this trade-off but lacks theoretical validation.
Links specific CACC design challenges to broader traffic efficiency and safety goals in CAV deployment, emphasizing throughput-stability balance.
Control theory, traffic flow dynamics, vehicular communication systems.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Multi-anticipation: Response to multiple predecessors' states
String stability: Perturbation attenuation in vehicle platoons
Lyapunov methods: Stability analysis tools for nonlinear/delayed systems
Multi-anticipation enables string stability; Lyapunov methods provide analytical foundation; stability conditions constrain sensitivity parameters.
First-order lower-level controller approximation; homogeneous vehicle dynamics; constant communication delay (0.1s).
Provides closed-form stability conditions for previously intractable multi-anticipative models, advancing predictive control theory for CAVs.
Methodology: Lyapunov function method for delay-free systems; Lyapunov functional/LMI approach for delayed systems; circular road simulations with perturbation propagation analysis.
Novel application of Lyapunov methods to multi-anticipative CACC; methods validated against numerical simulations and transfer function benchmarks.
Experimental ACC data (OpenACC database) for parameter calibration; spacing/velocity/acceleration variables; preprocessing via equilibrium perturbation Ansatz.
Rigorous analytical derivations supplemented by 10^4s simulations; stability evaluated via perturbation growth/attenuation over wavelength spectrum.
Follows control-theoretic paradigm emphasizing state-space representations and stability margins, contrasting with transfer function approaches.
Results: Multi-anticipation reduces critical headway (1.5s→0.48s for 3 predecessors); delay ≤0.2s causes <5% stability margin reduction; instability transitions from long to short wavelength at high kg,n1.
Results validated against simulations; power law in wavelength parameterization shows robustness; sensitivity analysis confirms model predictability.
Argumentation_and_Logic: 1. Formulate CACC dynamics → 2. Derive stability conditions via Lyapunov methods → 3. Validate numerically → 4. Conduct sensitivity analysis → 5. Evaluate delay impacts.
Theoretical derivation → Numerical verification → Parameter sensitivity exploration → Practical implications.
Strengths: Cross-validation with multiple methods. Weakness: Sufficient-but-not-necessary delay stability conditions addressed via LMI conservatism analysis.
Strengths_and_Limitations: First closed-form stability conditions for multi-anticipative CACC; power law discovery; negligible delay impact substantiated.
Assumes homogeneous vehicles and first-order lower-level controller; excludes fuel-engine dynamics.
Control-theoretic framework limits exploration of human-AV interaction or macroscopic traffic impacts.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Positions as bridge between control theory and traffic engineering, resolving ACC stability-capacity trade-off.
Technical terminology (e.g., 'string stability', 'neutral type delay'); authoritative tone; emphasizes methodological innovation.
Cites experimental studies (Gunter, Ciuffo) to justify problem urgency; uses theoretical references (Krasovskii) to establish analytical credibility.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Multi-anticipative CACC ensures stability at low headways; communication delays ≤0.2s are negligible; wavelength instability follows power law without acceleration sensitivity.
Extend to heterogeneous traffic; incorporate higher-fidelity lower-level controllers; explore mixed autonomy scenarios.
